indexhtml.pagetitle: The Transportation Impacts of Vehicle-for-Hire in the City of Toronto
indexhtml.introp: Private Tranpsportation Companies (PTC) trips have grown rapidly since the service was first licensed by the City in September 2016. Understanding these new services and their impact is key to developing policies that support the benefits of these services while minimizing adverse effects on traffic, the environment and the equity of mobility services.
indexhtml.DVpara: Here, we provide an interactive exploration of the results of this report, organized around these 3 central questions:
indexhtml.Q1: What are the trends and patterns in vehicle-for-hire travel in the City?
indexhtml.Q2: How has this travel impacted the transportation network?
indexhtml.Q3: How have travel choices evolved in Toronto?
indexhtml.section0: PTC trips have grown by 180% in 2.5 years
indexhtml.section0-text1: PTC trips have grown rapidly since the service was first licensed by the City in September 2016, increasing to 176,000 daily trips in March 2019 – an increase of over 180%. Most of these trips were made in the district of Toronto and East York, which in September 2018 accounted for 61% of the total number of daily trips, followed by North York (16%), Etobicoke York (13), and Scarborough (9%).
indexhtml.growthtsTitle: Average daily PTC Trips, September 2016 – March 2019
indexhtml.section1: Toronto compared with other PTC cities
indexhtml.section1-text1: Yet, the City of Toronto is still in the early stages of PTC adoption relative to other cities in North America. For context, in Chicago, a city of comparable population where PTCs started 3 years earlier than in Toronto, there are almost twice the number of daily trips than in Toronto (330,400 vs. 176,000), whereas daily PTC trips in Toronto are currently comparable to San Francisco (170,000 trips/day), a city about 3 times smaller in population. While cities can differ greatly in their regulatory context, demographic makeup, and the size and population density of their urban cores, trends in PTC growth suggest that the PTC trip market in the City of Toronto is not saturated and that growth in trips will likely continue for the foreseeable future.
indexhtml.cityScatterTitle: Size of PTC Trip Markets in Other Jurisdictions
indexhtml.section3: Where is the largest volume of PTC trips?
indexhtml.section3-text1: The largest volume of PTC trips is concentrated downtown where PTCs account for between 5 and 8% of overall daily traffic in Downtown Neighbourhoods. The busiest neighbourhood is Waterfront Communities-The Island, bordered by Bathurst St, Queen St/Front St, the Don River, and Lake Ontario.
indexhtml.section3-text2: The map below is coloured by the proportion of traffic accounted for by PTC trips in each neighbourhood for xx different selectable periods of the day (AM peak, ...).
indexhtml.section4-text1a: While we don't have data about individual trips, we do know total pick-up and drop-off locations and times. Looking a bit closer at different parts of the city tells us different stories that give some clues about why people are using PTCs. The line chart below shows the number of trips in September 2018 made in each hour of the week, averaged by day of week, for a selected ward. The location of these trips is shown on the corresponding map. A second menu allows the option of seeing the data for all trips within the selected ward, only pick-ups from the ward, or only drop-offs into the ward.
indexhtml.section4-text1b: In Etobicoke North, during the Monday morning peak (7:00–9:00), a considerable number of drop-offs were made at Humber College near the bus terminal compared with the number of pick-ups (212 vs. 24, respectively, or 89%). Most of these drop-offs arrived from the same ward (647 out of 1370, or 47%), followed by Etobicoke Centre (142, or 10%), Humber River-Black Creek (120, or 9%), Etobicoke-Lakeshore (111, or 8%). So, many people who live near Humber College use PTCs to get to school in the mornings.
indexhtml.section4-text1c: In the suburbs, trips are more commuter-focused, since their Friday night and weekend profiles are smaller compared with the city average which is dominated by downtown activity. For example, selecting Scarborough-Agincourt from the dropdown menu shows that there are strong peaks on weekday mornings and reduced Friday/Saturday night activity compared with the city average. Moving the cursor over the Monday morning peak shows on the adjacent map several drop-off locations (pink circles) around Sunnybrook Health Sciences Centre and the Hollands Broadview Rehabilliation Hospital, whereas on Friday or Saturday evening the dropoffs (purple circles) clustered around the Don Mills entertainment complex.
indexhtml.hover-freeze: Click on the hoverline to freeze/unfreeze it over a particular hour.
